awd_titl_txt: Chemical Triggers for Magnetic Switching: Discovery and Control of Switching Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Matthew Shores of the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University is exploring new classes of transition metal complexes that can serve as molecular switches. Complexes that can exist in and reliably switch between two well-defined magnetic states offer the possibility for functional materials development at the nano- and molecular length scales. Along with fostering a fundamental approach to underdeveloped chemical processes, these results will inform design principles of anion sensors, switchable molecular magnets, and magnetic resonance contrast agents. The project combines several synthetic, measurement and computational techniques to provide diverse training for the graduate and undergraduate research students involved. The group’s expertise in magnetic measurements and data interpretation will promote discovery via several ongoing and new magnetic collaborations with inorganic and materials chemistry research groups around the country. 

Switchable molecular magnet behavior has been reported with respect to spin crossover complexes and single molecule magnets.  Refinement of desirable properties is complicated by their extreme sensitivity to environmental conditions. To nullify serendipity in their development, Shores' research aims to decipher the impact of noncovalent interactions on the local electronic structure of transition metal complexes. The specific research goals for this project are the  development of predictive models for magnetic state switching through computational techniques; the refinement of the foundational principles of noncovalent interactions to aid in the design of chemical triggers; and the establishment of a structure function relationship with respect to minute distortions and magnetic properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, the research group of Professor Matthew Shores in the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University (CSU) focused on the synthesis and characterization of molecular inorganic compounds, toward the design of species that controllably change their magnetic properties depending on interaction with external chemical factors like anions, guest species, and solvent molecules. The fundamental studies are intended to contribute to the development of novel chemical sensors, switches, and magnetic resonance contrast agents. Studies on vanadium, chromium, iron, and nickel complexes were carried out. Key results are highlighted below:

1. We continued to explore synthetic chemistry around post-synthetic modification of Fe(II) spin crossover complexes, toward development of new magnetic resonance contrast agents. Whereas Fe(II) spin crossover complexes are known to show significant changes in geometry at the metal center when switching between high- and low-spin states, we also found a ligand set where the ligand conformation changes, due to pi-pi interactions between ligand arms. In principle, this offers a second switching mechanism that could be impacted by host-guest interactions.

2. In collaboration with Prof. Tony Rappé (CSU), we developed a way to visualize non-covalent interactions between separate ligands in metal complexes. We applied this understanding toward building a structural model that could separate low-spin-only complexes from spin-crossover complexes with >90% accuracy over a set of 3000 Fe(II) compounds. In the future, the structural model could be applied to the prediction of compounds that will show magnetic switching, at a very low computational cost.

3. Serendipitously, we discovered a multidentate ligand set that, when bound to Fe(II), shows a very large temperature dependence in its magnetic resonance signals. This phenomenon could be relevant to applications in molecular-level thermometry.

4. We also investigated synthetic variation on a Ni(III) complex with a tetradentate (cyclam) ligand, to figure out what structural parameters control observed slow relaxation of magnetization, a key factor in developing so-called single-molecule magnets. We found that the nuclear magnetic spin of axial ligands does not turn on/off slow relaxation. We did find that particle size and degree of deuteration are important factors, indicating that intermolecular interactions are key in developing single molecule magnets with species that have only one unpaired electron.

We continued to collaborate with other synthetic chemists across the country on magnetic data collection and interpretation for their novel compounds. These activities broadened access to magnetic characterization instrumentation for the wider chemistry community.

Students and postdocs were trained in the interdisciplinary area of chemical synthesis, physical characterization, and computational modeling, and results were disseminated through invited talks and publications. Four PhD dissertations featured work supported by this project.
